title: How to Cook Ham Joint

steps.headline: Place your ham joint in a saucepan and cover it with water.
steps.description: Grab a saucepan or similar cooking pot that’s large enough to hold your ham joint. Place the gammon inside the pan, then pour in enough water to cover the entire cut of meat. For extra taste, use a flavored liquid like perry or cider instead of water.

steps.headline: Add herbs, fruits, and other ingredients to taste.
steps.description: To give your gammon additional flavor characteristics, add in a variety of cooking ingredients you think taste good with ham. This may include anything from herbs and vegetables to fruits and citrus. Use ingredients like sliced onions, sliced lemons, peppercorns, and bay leaves to give your gammon a rich, hearty flavor. Try adding apple, orange, or pear slices to give your gammon the fun, fruity flavor many associate with the holidays.

steps.headline: Bring your saucepan to a boil, then lower the heat and put a lid on it.
steps.description: Place your saucepan on a stove or burner and set the temperature to high. Once the water starts to boil, lower the temperature to bring the water to a simmer. Then, place a cooking lid on top of the saucepan. The lid will trap in steam, helping your ham joint retain moisture.

steps.headline: Let the dish simmer for 25 minutes per 1.1 lb (500 g) of gammon.
steps.description: Your cooking time will depend entirely on how large your ham joint is. Small joints may only need to boil for 30 minutes to an hour, but large joints can take 2 hours or more. Cooking time may vary between kitchens, so check your gammon often to make sure it doesn’t overcook.

steps.headline: Check the ham joint regularly and remove any excess froth.
steps.description: While cooking, check on your ham joint every 15 to 30 minutes. If any froth or scum rises to the surface, scoop it up using a cooking spoon and discard it in your sink.

steps.headline: Remove your gammon when you can easily pierce it with a fork.
steps.description: Before taking out your ham joint, grab a general purpose fork or knife and press it into the thickest part of the dish. If your utensil goes in and out of the gammon with no resistance, it’s ready to eat. If the meat is still tough, it needs to cook a little longer.

steps.headline: Give your gammon 15 minutes to rest before serving it.
steps.description: After you remove your ham joint from the pan, set it on a large plate and let it finish cooking for about 15 minutes. Then, feel free to carve and serve it. If you have any leftovers, place them inside an airtight container and store them in your fridge for 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to about 325 °F (163 °C).
steps.description: Clean your oven out if necessary, then create a space in the center to hold your ham joint. When you’re ready to start cooking, preheat the oven to approximately 325 °F (163 °C).

steps.headline: Place you gammon in a roasting tin lined with aluminum foil.
steps.description: Grab a roasting tin or casserole dish that’s large enough to hold your ham joint. Line the inside with aluminium cooking foil, then place your gammon in the center of the dish.

steps.headline: Fill the tin ¾ of the way up with water.
steps.description: To make sure your ham joint turns out moist and juicy, fill the area surrounding the meat with water. If you’d like, pour water over the top of the ham joint as well. To add more taste dimensions, use fruit juice, cola, wine, or another flavored liquid instead of water.

steps.headline: Cover the ham joint with aluminum foil.
steps.description: Before putting your ham joint in the oven, place a few sheets of aluminium foil on top of it. Make sure the foil sits tight against the ham joint, that way your meat will retain as much moisture as possible.

steps.headline: Bake the dish for 30 minutes per 1 lb (450 g) of gammon.
steps.description: Like regular ham, the amount of time necessary to bake your ham joint will vary based on how large it is. Small cuts should be done fairly quickly, often within an hour, but larger cuts may take 2 or more hours. To help your ham joint cook more quickly, consider cutting the meat into smaller chunks before putting it in the oven.

steps.headline: Check your dish every 15 to 30 minutes and add more liquid if necessary.
steps.description: Throughout the cooking process, open your oven to see how you ham joint is doing. If necessary, peel back the foil slightly to make sure the meat isn’t burning. If there’s no water or cooking liquid left in the container, add some.

steps.headline: Take out the ham joint once you can pierce it with a fork.
steps.description: Before removing your gammon, press a standard kitchen fork or knife into the plumpest part of the cut. If the meat is too tough to pierce easily, let it bake some more. If it is easy to pierce and gives little resistance, take it out of the oven and let it rest before serving. For safety, use heat-resistant gloves when taking things out of the oven.

steps.headline: Let your ham joint cool for 15 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Once you pull your gammon out of the oven, set it on a flat table and let it rest for at least 15 minutes. This will give it time to cool down and finish cooking. After eating, place any leftover gammon in an airtight container and keep it in your fridge for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Stop cooking your ham joint about 20 minutes before it’s done.
steps.description: To make sure it doesn’t overcook, remove your gammon from the oven or boiling pot when it has between 20 and 30 minutes left to go. Glazing your ham joint now ensures that both the meat and glaze taste fresh and delicious.

steps.headline: Place your gammon in a baking dish if you boiled it.
steps.description: Take your saucepan off the stove and carefully pour out any leftover cooking liquid. Let the gammon cool down for a few minutes, then transfer it to a cooking tin or casserole dish lined with aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Cut off your ham joint’s rind.
steps.description: Using a sharp knife, cut off the rind surrounding your gammon along with a large amount of the connected fat. For the best glaze results, leave about 0.25 in (0.64 cm) of fat around the entire ham joint. To get the classic scored ham look, cut along the surface of your gammon in a zigzag pattern.

steps.headline: Cook water, honey, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
steps.description:
Grab a clean saucepan and fill it with 1 cup (240 ml) of water, 0.5 cups (120 ml) of honey, 0.25 cups (59 ml) of sugar, and 0.5  tsp (2.5 ml) of salt. Then, place the pan over a medium flame and let the mixture simmer until the sugar completely dissolves. Some other popular glaze mixtures include:
Brown sugar and pineapple slices
Maple syrup, mustard, red wine vinegar, and 5-spice powder
Honey, brown sugar, Sriracha, and chopped garlic
Cola and brown sugar

steps.headline: Cover your ham joint with the honey glaze sauce.
steps.description: Give your glaze sauce a few minutes to cool, then cover the top of your gammon with it. You can apply your glaze sauce by pouring it onto the ham joint, ladling it on with a spoon, or brushing it on with a basting brush.

steps.headline: Bake the ham joint at 350 °F (177 °C) for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: After applying the glaze sauce, place your gammon in an oven preheated to 350 °F (177 °C). Remove your ham joint once it becomes brown and shiny, a process that normally takes between 20 and 30 minutes. To avoid burning yourself, put on heat-resistant gloves when taking things out of the oven. No matter how you originally cooked your gammon, you’ll have to add the glaze using an oven.
